scopecontent.p: This extensive graphic collection consists of posters produced prior to and during World War II. Most are printed by the U.S. Government, and the propagandistic message of the posters is strong, promoting patriotism and civilian support of the country's involvement in the war. Based on the printing date, some recruitment posters were published before the United States entered the war. One example is the 1940 poster encouraging enlistment in the Navy in order to "join our expanded fleet." While some posters urge recruitment into the various military branches, others commemorate specific battles or recount individual experiences. Other posters are directed toward the civilian worker, rallying them to do their part and reminding them of the sacrifices servicemen are making on their behalf. Gender issues are also evident, particularly in the WAVES recruitment posters, inviting women to do man-size jobs. Some posters were put out by business concerns. Most of these posters were also patriotic declarations, with the company noted at the bottom. Others, however, tied-in patriotism with their business, such as the Aldine Theatre in Philadelphia, which promoted a war-related movie and American Express Travelers Cheques selling war bonds and stamps. There is also a series of posters of the Pennsylvania Railroad, promoting its vital role in the war effort by transporting men, supplies and ammunition, and discouraging civilian use of the trains during weekends and holidays since that was when servicemen were traveling. Some of the artists were prominent painters and illustrators of the time including Ben Shahn and David Stone Martin. A series of smaller posters offer civilians a variety of directives, including the need to eat well and stay healthy, turn out lights, and to keep quiet about military movements.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
